title: Half of teething toys pulled from sale after failing choke hazard tests, study reveals
text:
A string of teething toys have been pulled from sale after failing safety tests.

Which? analysed 15 products, with half found to pose a choking hazard.

The items had all featured in ‘top ten’ lists of recommended toys, or were prominently listed on Amazon.

A string of teething toys have been pulled from sale after failing safety tests. Which? analysed 15 products, with half found to pose a choking hazard. The items had all featured in ‘top ten’ lists of recommended toys, or were prominently listed on Amazon

They underwent a ‘tension test’, assessing whether any parts that detach are small enough to be swallowed or inhaled, and an ‘impaction test’, examining whether the toy could block the throat of a child too young to sit up unaided.

Five products on Amazon failed both: the Silvio baby teether and toothbrush, the Gupamiga toothbrush corn, the Iceblueor giraffe teether, SLGOL’s silicone teething toys and the Gummee Glove. All five have been removed from sale.

A Matchstick Monkey bought from John Lewis failed the tension test, while a ‘moustache’ teether sold by slumber-roo.co.uk failed the impaction test. The latter has been taken off sale while the website investigates.

John Lewis said the Matchstick Monkey ‘adheres to international safety regulations’, adding: ‘In our assessment, we believe this product remains safe and we continue to sell it.’
description:
Which? analysed 15 products, with half found to pose a choking hazard.
The items had all featured in 'top ten' lists of recommended toys, or were prominently listed on Amazon.
